intro: Peucedanum achaicum, commonly known as Persian cumin or wild cumin, is a flowering plant native to the regions of the Caucasus and Central Asia. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots, parsley, and dill, and is characterized by its finely divided leaves and small yellow flowers. The plant is typically found in rocky or sandy soils and thrives in temperate climates. It produces small, dry fruits that contain aromatic seeds used in traditional medicine and culinary applications. Its botanical features make it an important species for both ecological and medicinal studies.
